page.title: 05HONING WOODYARD
page.content: On a freezing February 7th.1985 our class visited Kenny Firman at his woodyard in Honing. We entered the workshop and it was a pleasure to get out of the biting wind. A local farmhouse is being rethatched and Mr. Firman was busy making liggers and brotches from hazel billets harvested locally at Beeston St. Lawrence. Brotches are used to hold the thatch in place and liggers for making the patterns in diamonds and squares along the ridge thatch. Mr. Firman was sitting astride a wooden stool with a wooden peg protruding up at the far end. He used a billhook to firstly split the end of the hazel and then skilfully pushed the split end against the peg thus splitting the hazel along its length. Honing Estate, the landlords,want to move the woodyard to another site in the village.
